technology specialist at ericsson so these are the agenda items that we
will walk you through today uh first is yg and why cloud native
5g system architecture and its complexity major challenging telco requirements and
different telco traffic classes and also scenario of when to use secondary network
and how nsm can help and which will be followed by a demo using network service mesh
why cloud native for 5g the main reasons include speed by adapting market changes
quickly scale micro service architecture allow scalability with telco grade reliability
efficiency by simplifying complex telco network functions and also increase capacity flexibly when
service demands grows why kubernetes and
uh what do we get from kubernetes primary networking model so kubernetes is a cncf uh recommended
cloud platform it provides life cycle management scaling and auto healing service discovery external service
exposure load balancing and this is the 5g system architecture
based on 3gpp reference the rectangular boxes represent different network function
and that basically does network functions with most of them being software based and you also see interfaces between
different network functions so some of the network functions examples are network slice
selection function nssf network exposure function nef network repository function packet
policy control function unified data management application function etc you also see
below user equipment which is a mobile laptop etc radio access network user plane
function and data networks so the highlighted area uh the
interfaces in this highlighted area are service-based interfaces
so basically they can be implemented using kubernetes primary networking because they are http 2
or api based so they're based interfaces so they can be implemented using kubernetes primary
networking the interfaces highlighted in the below area
are non-sbi non-service based interfaces they are telco interfaces over
l2 l3 the telco interfaces are with high requirements such as a high performance a low jitter
high bandwidth and not suitable for kubernetes networking example is user data plane traffic
between a user equipment and data network which is mostly encapsulated in gtp
protocol so for non stand service based interfaces we need to use secondary
networks as humanities network cannot handle them and need uh different networking secondary
networking solutions such as motors or network service mesh so based on uh all these details
why we are showing this picture in this slide is because to show how complex uh
the architecture is and also to highlight the challenging requirements that telco has
so based on that we are outlining the major challenging telco requirements
one of them is operator requirement on end-to-end vpn separation due to security or
legacy reasons operators expect end-to-end vpn separation from external network till
application boards with kubernetes single network model only external traffic separation is
possible and no end to end vpn separation and the second a challenging requirement
is that support for no nat protocol so protocols that are not sensitive like session initiation
protocol ship or media and the third main challenging
requirement is eager sweep for outgoing traffic originating from application ports so outgoing traffic
from uh port leaves kubernetes cluster with ip address of worker nodes
the outgoing traffic need to come out with a virtual ip address without nat one reason why this is required is the
ip address limit because of too many ips of uh for outgoing traffic and customer expects
common ip for incoming and outgoing and another major reason uh requirement
is uh support for non-ip protocols and uh last but not least we need to support
high performance traffic that is traffic with low latency low jitter high number of
packets per second and high bandwidth so based on these requirements there is
a need to support different traffic types so here we outline different telco traffic classes based on
different traffic types characteristics and packets per seconds
so first classification is a low performance with high functionality
that is it doesn't require uh too much latency so no latency sensitive uh
it includes protocols that supports a protocol level encryption but it the traffic requires services
like uh load balancer service discovery purchase management etc
and the number of packets per second that needs to handle is like 0 to 1 million packets per second
and example is operational and maintenance protocols like snmp netconf etc
and the other classification is high performance low function which is only a delay data link or l2
level they need to handle high performance user plane or data plane implemented normally using dpdk and
sriov the traffic needs to handle 5 million packets per second and more example is user plane function
radio access network etc there is also a middle category that is a medium performance
which lies between these two categories they include high performance control plane or low performance data plane and the
traffic that needs to handle one to five million packets per second example is a diameter sip etc
so with these details anders francien will show you visualization of when to use secondary
network in the next slide so anders
